agent.tooltip.agentId: The Agent ID is a unique identifier of an Agent that cannot be changed during the Agent's lifetime. For Agent IDs most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
agent.tooltip.agentName: The Agent Name is a unique designation of an Agent that can be changed. Agents are assigned to jobs by their Agent Name. For Agent Names most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
agent.tooltip.title: The Title of an Agent can be specified as desired.
agent.tooltip.agentNameAliases: An Agent can be assigned a number of Alias Names. The Agent can be assigned to a job or File Order Source using its Alias Name. For Alias Names most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
agent.tooltip.url: The URL of an Agent specifies the protocol, HTTP or HTTPS, the host name or IP address and the port of the Agent, e.g. http://localhost:4445
agent.tooltip.asStandaloneAgent: A Standalone Agent or a Director Agent of an Agent Cluster can act as a Cluster Watch. The Agent specified will be created as a Standalone Agent if this checkbox is checked.
agent.tooltip.primaryDirectorId: The Director Agent ID is a unique identifier of a Director Agent that cannot be changed during the Agent's lifetime. For Director Agent IDs most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
agent.tooltip.hidden: Agents can be hidden to prevent them from being displayed in the JOC Cockpit user interface. This applies to the DASHBOARD view as well as to all occurrences where Agents are assigned.

cluster.tooltip.agentClusterName: The Agent Cluster Name is a unique identifier of the Agent Cluster that cannot be changed during the Agent Cluster's lifetime. For Agent Cluster Names most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
cluster.tooltip.subagentId: The Subagent ID is a unique identifier of a Director Agent that cannot be changed during the Director Agent's lifetime. For Subagent IDs most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
cluster.tooltip.title: The Title of an Agent Cluster can be specified as desired.
cluster.tooltip.url: The URL of a Director Agent specifies the protocol, HTTP or HTTPS, the host name or IP address and the port of the Director Agent, e.g. http://localhost:4445
cluster.tooltip.withGenerateSubagentCluster: A Director Agent can be set up as a separate Subagent Cluster that includes this single Director Agent. This allows jobs to be run specifically on a Director Agent.
cluster.tooltip.agentNameAliases: An Agent Cluster can be assigned a number of Alias Names. The Agent Cluster can be assigned to a job or File Order Source using its Alias Name. For Alias Names most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.

subagent.tooltip.clusterName: The Subagent Cluster Name is a unique identifier of the Subagent Cluster that cannot be changed during the Subagent Cluster's lifetime. For Subagent Cluster Names most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
subagent.tooltip.title: The Title of a Subagent Cluster can be specified as desired.

subagent.tooltip.subagentId: The Subagent ID is a unique identifier of a Subagent that cannot be changed during the Subagent's lifetime. For Subagent IDs most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
subagent.tooltip.title: The Title of a Subagent can be specified as desired.
subagent.tooltip.url: The URL of a Subagent specifies the protocol, HTTP or HTTPS, the host name or IP address and the port of the Subagent, e.g. http://localhost:4445
subagent.tooltip.withGenerateSubagentCluster: A Subagent can be set up as a separate Subagent Cluster that includes this single Subagent. This allows jobs to be run specifically on a Subagent.

tooltip.descriptorId: The Descriptor ID is a unique identifier of the Descriptor.
tooltip.title: The Title specifies the purpose of the Descriptor.
tooltip.account: The Account that manages the Descriptor.
tooltip.scheduled: The target date for which rollout based on the Descriptor is scheduled.
tooltip.created: The point in time when the Descriptor was created.

tooltip.licenseKeyFile: The path to the License Key File is expected. The file represents a certificate in .pem format and unlocks the licensed binary code.
tooltip.licenseBinFile: The path to the License Binary File is expected. The file contains binary code that is not subject to the Open Source License, e.g. the cluster functions of JOC Cockpit and Controller. The binary code is unlocked by a License Key File.

placeholder.primaryControllerCert: Enter path to Primary Controller instance's Certificate
placeholder.secondaryControllerCert: Enter path to Secondary Controller instance's Certificate
placeholder.primaryJocCert: Enter path to Primary JOC Cockpit instance's Certificate
placeholder.secondaryJocCert: Enter path to Secondary JOC Cockpit instance's Certificate

tooltip.primaryControllerCert: The Primary Controller Certificate is required by Agents that are set up for HTTPS mutual authentication (default).
tooltip.secondaryControllerCert: The Secondary Controller Certificate is required by Agents that are set up for HTTPS mutual authentication (default).
tooltip.primaryJocCert: The Primary JOC Cockpit Certificate is required by Controller instances that are set up for HTTPS mutual authentication (default).
tooltip.secondaryJocCert: The Secondary JOC Cockpit Certificate is required by Controller instances that are set up for HTTPS mutual authentication (default).

tooltip.agentId: The Agent ID is unique and identifies the Agent. The identifier cannot be changed during the lifetime of an Agent.
tooltip.host: The Host on which the Agent is installed.
tooltip.port: The port through which a connection to the host is established. This is often port 22 for SSH connections.
tooltip.method: The Authentication Method for the SSH connection to the Agent's host. The private/public key method is supported.
tooltip.user: The Account to authenticate the SSH connection to the Agent's host.
tooltip.keyFile: The path to the Key File for authenticating the SSH connection to the Agent's host.
tooltip.packageLocation: The path to the location of the software installation package on the Agent's host.
tooltip.execPre: The command for pre-processing is executed on the Agent's host before the package of the software installation is extracted. An operating system command can be specified. With the specification 'StopService' the service of the Agent is stopped under Unix and Windows.
tooltip.execPost: Command for post-processing is executed after extraction of the package of the software installation on the Agent's host. An operating system command can be specified. With the specification 'StartService', the service of the Agent is started under Unix and Windows.
tooltip.makeService: The Service of the Agent under Unix or Windows is set up.
tooltip.release: The software version of the Agent.
tooltip.tarball: The Tarball of the software installation of the Agent. For Unix this is a .tar.gz archive, for Windows a .zip archive.
tooltip.home: The Agent's installation directory contains binary files and executable files. Under Unix, the directory /opt/sos-berlin.com/js7/agent is often used. Under Windows, C:/Program Files/sos-berlin.com/js7/agent is often used.
tooltip.data: The Agent's data directory contains, among other things, configuration files and log files in the sub-directories 'config' and 'logs'. Under Unix, the directory /var/sos-berlin.com/js7/agent is often used. Under Windows, C:/ProgramData/sos-berlin.com/js7/agent is often used.
tooltip.homeOwner: The user account that owns the Agent's home directory.
tooltip.dataOwner: The user account that owns the Agent's data directory.
tooltip.runUser: The user account that is used for the Agent service.
tooltip.httpPort: The Agent listens to this HTTP port, which is used to accept commands from the Instance Start Script and, if applicable, commands from the Controller. For use with the Instance Start Script, a local network interface can be specified, e.g. localhost:4445. If a Controller from another host communicates with the Agent via this port, a public network interface can be specified, e.g. host.example.com:4445.
tooltip.httpsPort: The Agent listens this HTTPS port, which is used to receive commands from the Controller. The port must be accessible for the Controller in the network.
tooltip.javaHome: The Java installation directory frequently is specified by the JAVA_HOME environment variable.
tooltip.javaOptions: Java Options can be specified for example to increase the Heap Site as with -Xmx512m.
tooltip.controllerId: The Controller ID references the Controller to which the Agent is dedicated.
tooltip.keyStore: The Keystore contains the Agent's private key, which is used for HTTPS connections to the Agent.
tooltip.keyStorePassword: The Keystore is protected by a password
tooltip.keyPassword: The private key is protected by a password. With the commonly used PKCS12 format for keystores, the password of the keystore and of the key must match.
tooltip.keyAlias: The Key Alias can be used when a keystore contains multiple private keys. The alias name determines the private key to be used for HTTPS connections to the Agent.
tooltip.trustStore: The Truststore contains the public certificate of the Certificate Authority that signed the Agent's certificate.
tooltip.trustStorePassword: The Truststore is protected by a password
tooltip.templates: The path to a directory containing template files for configuring the Agent, e.g. 'agent.conf'. The directory may have a sub-directory 'private' with further configuration files.
tooltip.serviceName: The name of the systemd Service.
tooltip.serviceDir: Specifies the path to the systemd Service Directory, default: /usr/lib/systemd/system, for example /etc/systemd/system.
tooltip.forceSudo: Force use of sudo for any operation on directories and files.

placeholder.serviceDir: Enter path to systemd Service Directory

tooltip.host: The Host on which the Controller is installed.
tooltip.port: The port through which a connection to the host is established. This is often port 22 for SSH connections.
tooltip.method: The Authentication Method for the SSH connection to the Controller's host. The private/public key method is supported.
tooltip.user: The Account to authenticate the SSH connection to the Controller's host.
tooltip.keyFile: The path to the Key File for authenticating the SSH connection to the Controller's host.
tooltip.packageLocation: The path to the location of the software installation package on the Controller's host.
tooltip.execPre: The command for pre-processing is executed on the Controller's host before the package of the software installation is extracted. An operating system command can be specified. With the specification 'StopService' the service of the Controller is stopped under Unix and Windows.
tooltip.execPost: Command for post-processing is executed after extraction of the package of the software installation on the Controller's host. An operating system command can be specified. With the specification 'StartService', the service of the Controller is started under Unix and Windows.
tooltip.makeService: The Service of the Controller under Unix or Windows is set up.
tooltip.release: The software version of the Controller.
tooltip.tarball: The Tarball of the software installation of the Controller. For Unix this is a .tar.gz archive, for Windows a .zip archive.
tooltip.home: The Controller's installation directory contains binary files and executable files. Under Unix, the directory /opt/sos-berlin.com/js7/controller is often used. Under Windows, C:/Program Files/sos-berlin.com/js7/controller is often used.
tooltip.data: The Controller's data directory contains, among other things, configuration files and log files in the sub-directories 'config' and 'logs'. Under Unix, the directory /var/sos-berlin.com/js7/controller is often used. Under Windows, C:/ProgramData/sos-berlin.com/js7/controller is often used.
tooltip.homeOwner: The user account that owns the Controller's home directory.
tooltip.dataOwner: The user account that owns the Controller's data directory.
tooltip.runUser: The user account that is used for the Controller service.
tooltip.httpPort: The Controller listens to this HTTP port, which is used to accept commands from the Instance Start Script and commands from JOC Cockpit. For use with the Instance Start Script, a local network interface can be specified, e.g. localhost:4444. If JOC Cockpit communicates from another host with the Controller via this port, a public network interface can be specified, e.g. host.example.com:4444.
tooltip.httpsPort: The Controller listens to this HTTPS port, which is used to receive commands from JOC Cockpit. The port must be accessible for JOC Cockpit in the network.
tooltip.javaHome: The Java installation directory frequently is specified by the JAVA_HOME environment variable.
tooltip.javaOptions: Java Options can be specified for example to increase the Heap Site as with -Xmx512m.
tooltip.jocRef: The reference to a JOC Cockpit instance that is used to manage the Controller.
tooltip.controllerId: The Controller ID is a unique identifier of the Controller. This identifier cannot be changed during the lifetime of a Controller.
tooltip.keyStore: The Keystore contains the Controller's private key, which is used for HTTPS connections to the Controller.
tooltip.keyStorePassword: The Keystore is protected by a password
tooltip.keyPassword: The private key is protected by a password. With the commonly used PKCS12 format for keystores, the password of the keystore and of the key must match.
tooltip.keyAlias: The Key Alias can be used when a keystore contains multiple private keys. The alias name determines the private key to be used for HTTPS connections to the Controller.
tooltip.trustStore: The Truststore contains the public certificate of the Certificate Authority that signed the Controller's certificate.
tooltip.trustStorePassword: The Truststore is protected by a password
tooltip.controllerCert: The path to the Controller's Certificate file (*.pem, *.crt).
tooltip.templates: The path to a directory containing template files for configuring the Controller, e.g. 'controller.conf'. The directory may have a sub-directory 'private' with further configuration files.
tooltip.serviceName: The name of the systemd Service.
tooltip.serviceDir: Specifies the path to the systemd Service Directory, default: /usr/lib/systemd/system, for example /etc/systemd/system.
tooltip.forceSudo: Force use of sudo for any operation on directories and files.

tooltip.jocInstanceId: The JOC Cockpit Instance ID is a unique number that specifies the instance in a JOC Cockpit cluster.
tooltip.jocClusterId: The JOC Cockpit Cluster ID is a common identifier used by all JOC Cockpit instances in the same cluster.
tooltip.ordering: Ascening order of the JOC Cockpit instance in the DASHSBOARD view.
tooltip.host: The Host on which the JOC Cockpit is installed.
tooltip.port: The port through which a connection to the host is established. This is often port 22 for SSH connections.
tooltip.method: The Authentication Method for the SSH connection to the JOC Cockpit's host. The private/public key method is supported.
tooltip.user: The Account to authenticate the SSH connection to the JOC Cockpit's host.
tooltip.keyFile: The path to the Key File for authenticating the SSH connection to the JOC Cockpit's host.
tooltip.packageLocation: The path to the location of the software installation package on the JOC Cockpit's host.
tooltip.execPre: The command for pre-processing is executed on the JOC Cockpit's host before the package of the software installation is extracted. An operating system command can be specified. With the specification 'StopService' the service of the JOC Cockpit is stopped under Unix and Windows.
tooltip.execPost: Command for post-processing is executed after extraction of the package of the software installation on the JOC Cockpit's host. An operating system command can be specified. With the specification 'StartService', the service of the JOC Cockpit is started under Unix and Windows.
tooltip.makeService: The Service of the JOC Cockpit under Unix or Windows is set up.
tooltip.release: The software version of the JOC Cockpit.
tooltip.tarball: The Tarball of the software installation of the JOC Cockpit. For Unix this is a .tar.gz archive, for Windows a .zip archive.
tooltip.setupDir: The Setup Directory is used to extract the installation tarball. A temporary location can be used.
tooltip.home: The JOC Cockpit's installation directory contains binary files and executable files. Under Unix, the directory /opt/sos-berlin.com/js7/joc is often used. Under Windows, C:/Program Files/sos-berlin.com/js7/joc is often used.
tooltip.data: The JOC Cockpit's data directory contains, among other things, configuration files and log files in the sub-directories 'resources/joc' and 'logs'. Under Unix, the directory /var/sos-berlin.com/js7/joc is often used. Under Windows, C:/ProgramData/sos-berlin.com/js7/joc is often used.
tooltip.homeOwner: The user account that owns the JOC Cockpit's home directory.
tooltip.dataOwner: The user account that owns the JOC Cockpit's data directory.
tooltip.runUser: The user account that is used for the JOC Cockpit service.
tooltip.title: The Title of the JOC Cockpit instance is visible in the DASHBOARD view.
tooltip.securityLevel: The security level of JOC Cockpit rules, among other things, the handling of signing certificates for rollout of workflows.
tooltip.dbmsConfig: DBMS Hibernate Configuration File (hibernate.cfg.xml) specifies the database connection.
tooltip.dbmsDriver: DBMS JDBC Driver File (*.jar) establishes the connection to the database. A number of JDBC Driver Files ship with JOC Cockpit. Users can specify their own version of a DBMS JDBC Driver File.
tooltip.dbmsInit: DBMS initialisation involves setting up objects in the database. This can be done at the installation time 'byInstaller', at the start time 'byJoc' or not 'off'. In the latter case, users set up the database objects themselves.
tooltip.httpPort: The JOC Cockpit listens to this HTTP port by which users can access the GUI. The port must be accessible for users in the network. A public network interface can be specified, e.g. host.example.com:4446.
tooltip.httpsPort: The JOC Cockpit listens to this HTTPS port by which users can access the GUI. The port must be accessible for users in the network.
tooltip.isUser: Installation is performed in the context of the User Account.
tooltip.isPreserveEnv: Installation using 'sudo' preserves environment variables, for example JAVA_HOME.
tooltip.javaHome: The Java installation directory frequently is specified by the JAVA_HOME environment variable.
tooltip.javaOptions: Java Options can be specified for example to increase the Heap Site as with -Xmx1g.
tooltip.responseDir: The Response Directory may contain files that are copied to the Setup Directory, e.g. joc_install.xml, DBMS JDBC Driver file or key file of the license.
tooltip.keyStore: The Keystore contains the JOC Cockpit's private key, which is used for HTTPS connections to the JOC Cockpit.
tooltip.keyStorePassword: The Keystore is protected by a password
tooltip.keyPassword: The private key is protected by a password. With the commonly used PKCS12 format for keystores, the password of the keystore and of the key must match.
tooltip.keyAlias: The Key Alias can be used when a keystore contains multiple private keys. The alias name determines the private key to be used for HTTPS connections to the JOC Cockpit.
tooltip.trustStore: The Truststore contains the public certificate of the Certificate Authority that signed the JOC Cockpit's certificate.
tooltip.trustStorePassword: The Truststore is protected by a password
tooltip.templates: The path to a directory containing template files for configuring the Controller, e.g. 'controller.conf'. The directory may have a sub-directory 'private' with further configuration files.
tooltip.jocCert: The path to the JOC Cockpit Certificate file (*.pem, *.crt).
tooltip.httpIni: The path to the Jetty HTTP Configuration File (http.ini) can be specified if specific settings for HTTP connections to JOC Cockpit are required.
tooltip.httpsIni: Jetty HTTPS Configuration File (https.ini)  can be specified if specific settings for HTTPS connections to JOC Cockpit are required.
tooltip.sslIni: Jetty SSL Configuration File (ssl.ini) can be specified if specific settings for HTTPS connections to JOC Cockpit are required.
tooltip.serviceName: The name of the systemd Service.
tooltip.serviceDir: Specifies the path to the systemd Service Directory, default: /usr/lib/systemd/system, for example /etc/systemd/system.
tooltip.forceSudo: Force use of sudo for any operation on directories and files.

info.tooltip.globalVariablesAndEmailSettings: Default Job Resources for global variables and e-mail settings
info.tooltip.workflowExampleForUnix: Workflow examples for use with Agents running for Unix
info.tooltip.workflowExampleForWindows: Workflow examples for use with Agents running for Windows
info.tooltip.invalidLicense: License is not valid. Reasons can include that the start date of the validity period has hot been reached or that the expiration date has been exceeded.
info.tooltip.jocMonitorEvent: The flag signals warnings and errors in the processing of orders, for example when jobs fail. The flag indicates warnings with the yellow color and errors with the red color. Clicking the flag displays the last 10 warnings and errors. Users find the full list of warnings and errors from the MONITOR->Notifications view.
info.tooltip.systemMonitorEvent: The flag signals warnings and errors of JS7 components, for example connection loss to the database. The flag indicates warnings with the yellow color and errors with the red color. Clicking the flag displays the last 10 warnings and errors. Users find the full list of warnings and errors from the MONITOR->Notifications view.
info.message.line1: To give you an easy start, we suggest that you download some presets that you can import into JOC Cockpit from the Configuration View. After import the Defaults.zip archive will create a folder with the same name that includes Job Resources to create global %Job Environment Variables% available to your shell jobs.
info.message.line2: The Examples.tar.gz and Examples.zip archives include examples for workflows and jobs for operation with Agents on Unix and Windows respectively. The examples can be helpful to create your own workflows and job dependencies. The examples correspond to what you find from the %JS7 - Online Demo% explanations.

inventory.message.workflowWithVariables: Only a single workflow with order variables is allowed

repository.label.addDraftVersion: use draft version if no deployed/released version exists
repository.tooltip.perDefaultStorageOfDeployedRelea: Per default storing deployed/released versions is preferentially recommended. Choosing both draft and deployed/released versions will result in drafts being stored only, if no deployed/released version exists. Choosing only draft versions will result in draft version being stored and no deployed/released versions. Draft versions are considered untested and therefore unsafe.

calendar.name: Calendars are used with Schedules that create orders for the days specified by the Calendar. For Calendar names most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
calendar.documentation: A reference to a Documentation can be added that will be displayed with the Calendar. The RESOURCES view allows to manage the documentation.
calendar.title: The Title of the Calendar can be specified as desired.
calendar.type: Calendars are created for working days or for non-working days. When assigning a Schedule a Calendar then in addition to a working day Calendar a non-working day Calendar can be assigned that limits the days for workflow execution.
calendar.validFrom: Optionally the start of the Calendar's validity period can be specified. No orders will be created by a Schedule prior to this date.
calendar.validTo: Optionally the end of the Calendar's validity period can be specified. No orders will be created by a Schedule beyond this date.

fileOrderSource.name: A File Order Source is used to watch a Directory for incoming files and to create an order for each file individually. This allows to start workflows automatically on arrival of files. For the name of the File Order Source most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
fileOrderSource.documentation: A reference to a Documentation can be added that will be displayed with the File Order Source. The RESOURCES view allows to manage the documentation.
fileOrderSource.title: The Title of the File Order Source can be specified as desired.
fileOrderSource.workflowName: A reference to a Workflow has to be added. An order will be created for this workflow on arrival of a file in the Directory that is watched for incoming files.
fileOrderSource.agent: The Agent has to be specified that performs file watching on the respective host on which the Agent is installed.
fileOrderSource.directory: The Directory is specified is watched for incoming files. Consider that the Directory is accessible for the Agent's host and account. The directory is specfied as an expression, for example a string '/tmp/files' or in combination with a function as in env('HOME') ++ '/files'
fileOrderSource.pattern: A regular expression Pattern specifies the path to files that the Directory is watched for. For example .* means any files, .*\.txt$ means any files with the .txt extension.
fileOrderSource.timeZone: When a file arrives then the Agent will create an order that includes the current date with its Order ID. This item specifies the time zone that is used for the date in the Order ID.
fileOrderSource.delay: A Delay is applied for which the Agent waits that an incoming file remains unchanged. Changes are detected from the file size and file timestamp. If the file changes, for example if the file is written to by some process, then once again the Delay will be applied and the check will be repeated until no further change occurs.

jobResource.name: A Job Resource is a set of variables that can be used by a number of workflows or jobs. There are two flavors: Arguments are assigned to JITL jobs and Java jobs, Environment Variables automatically become available with Shell jobs. Values of Environment Variables can use Arguments as in $argument. For the name of the Job Resource most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
jobResource.documentation: A reference to a Documentation can be added that will be displayed with the Job Resource. The RESOURCES view allows to manage the Documentation.
jobResource.title: The Title of the Job Resource can be specified as desired.

board.name: A Notice Board represents the dependencies between workflows. The respective PostNotices Instructions and ExpectNotices Instructions in workflows reference the Notice Board. The name of a Notice Board is unique in the inventory. For the name of the Notice Board most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
board.expectBoardName: A Notice Board represents the dependencies between workflows. The respective PostNotices Instructions and ExpectNotices Instructions in workflows reference the Notice Board. The name of a Notice Board is unique in the inventory.  For the name of the Notice Board most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
board.documentation: A reference to a Documentation can be added that will be displayed with the Notice Board. The RESOURCES view allows to manage the documentation.
board.title: The Title of the Notice Board can be specified as desired.
board.toNotice: The Notice ID for posting order is extracted from its Order ID to look up matching expecting orders.
board.endOfLife: The end-of-life period for the Notice determines its duration in the format hh:mm:ss, for example 01:30:00 for one and a half hours.
board.readingOrderToNoticeId: The Notice ID for expecting order is extracted from its Order ID and is used to look up matching posting orders.

lock.name: Resource Locks are used to implement mutual exclusion for a sequence of jobs. They can be used in the same workflow and across any workflows to limit parallellism of jobs. The name of a Resource Lock is unique in the inventory. For the name of the Resource Lock most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
lock.documentation: A reference to a Documentation can be added that will be displayed with the Resource Lock. The RESOURCES view allows to manage the documentation.
lock.title: The Title of the Resource Lock can be specified as desired.
lock.limit: If a Resource Lock is acquired in shared mode then each Resource Lock consumer specifies a weight that is calculated towards the capacity of the Resource Lock. If the capacity is exceeded then jobs have to wait until their weight matches the available capacity of the Resource Lock.

schedule.name: A Schedule is used to automatically create orders for a given workflow based on the Calendar assigned. The name of a Schedule is unique in the inventory. For the name of the Schedule most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
schedule.documentation: A reference to a Documentation can be added that will be displayed with the Schedule. The RESOURCES view allows to manage the documentation.
schedule.title: The Title of the Schedule can be specified as desired.
schedule.workflowName: A reference to one or more workflows has to be added for which orders are created.
schedule.planOrderAutomatically: Orders are planned automatically, i.e. based on the Daily Plan Service settings orders are created for the next few days in advance.
schedule.submitOrderToControllerWhenPlanned: Orders are automatically submitted to a Controller when planned. Based on the settings of the Daily Plan Service orders are submitted a number of days in advance.
schedule.orderName: The order name is a non-qualifying part of the order identifier. Users can freely specify the job name when creating schedules and adding on demand orders.
schedule.startNode: The start position of a job can be before the specified instruction in the workflow. The job starts from the specified position.
schedule.endNode: The end position of a job can be before the specified instruction in the workflow. The job ends before the specified position.
schedule.ignoreAdmissionTimes: The execution of jobs can be restricted by Admission Times of the jobs. This option ignores Admission Times and forces the start of jobs.

script.name: A Script Include is used to include recurring code snippets into a job script. The name of a Script Include is unique in the inventory. For the name of the Script Include most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
script.documentation: A reference to a Documentation can be added that will be displayed with the Script. The RESOURCES view allows to manage the documentation.
script.title: The Title of the Script Include can be specified as desired.
script.script: Depending on its use with job scripts the content of a Script Include can include Shell commands or Code for scripting languages such as Perl, PowerShell etc.
script.autocompleteShortCut: Hit Ctrl+Space to retrieve the list of available Script Includes

workflow.name: The name of a Workflow is unique in the inventory. Most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
workflow.jobResourceNames: References to Job Resources can be added that hold shared variables for use by a number of jobs and workflows. Any variables from the selected Job Resources can be used by any jobs in the Workflow.
workflow.documentation: A workflow or job can be assigned a Documentation that is displayed with the WORKFLOWS view. Documentations are managed with the RESOURCES view.
workflow.title: The Title of the Workflow can be specified as desired. The Title is displayed with the WORKFLOWS view.
workflow.timeZone: The time zone is used for calculation of Admission Times and for Cycle Instructions. By default the time zone specified from the user profile is used.
workflow.allowUndeclared: Allow undeclared variables from orders. This includes that an order can carry variables that are not checked for their data type or mandatory use. Jobs will fail when referencing undeclared variables that are not available from an order.

board.expectBoardName: The name of a Notice Board is unique in the inventory. Most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
board.boardNames: A number of Notice Board names can be specified for which Notices are created.
board.expectBoardExpression: The ExpectNotices Expression can be used to specify a single Notice Board and to specify Boolean logic: ( 'A-BOARD' || 'B-BOARD' ) && 'C-BOARD'. The Notice Board names are quoted and the && (and) operator and || (or) operator can be used optinally including bracketing
board.consumeBoardExpression: The ConsumeNotices Expression can be used to specify a single Notice Board and to specify Boolean logic: ( 'A-BOARD' || 'B-BOARD' ) && 'C-BOARD'. The Notice Board names are quoted and the && (and) operator and || (or) operator can be used optinally including bracketing

fail.message: The instruction allows to specify a Message that is attached the order and that becomes visible with the order history.
fail.uncatchable: An uncatchable error cannot be handled with a Try/Catch Instruction.
fail.returnCode: The Fail Instruction can be assigned a positive, non-zero Return Code that becomes visible with the order history. Non-zero Return Codes indicate failed execution.

finish.message: The instruction allows to specify a Message that is attached the order and that becomes visible with the order history.
finish.unsuccessful: By default the Finish Instruction makes orders leave the workflow with a successfuly history outcome. This checkbox can be used to make an order leave the workflow with an unsuccessful historic outcome.

options.stopOnFailure: The setting impacts instructions such as Lock, ConsumeNotices and Cycle. It causes orders in case of errors to remain with the current instruction instead of returning to the begin of the respective Lock, ConsumeNotices or Cycle Instruction.

fileWatch.directory: The Directory that is watched for incoming files.
fileWatch.regex: A regular expression specifies the Pattern for the paths of incoming files that a directory is watched for. For example .* means any files, .*\.txt$ means any files with a .txt extension.

fork.joinVariables: Variables of child orders in the branches of a Fork Instruction are added to the parent order when reaching the Join Instruction.
fork.joinIfFailed: A child order is terminated in case of failure. The parent order will be put to the FAILED state.

forkList.children: List variable for dynamic forking: expects the name of the order variable that holds a list of elements. For each element of the list variable a branch is created dynamically from the assigned ForkList instruction. The number of list variable elements determines the number of parallel branches of the ForkList instruction that are executed in parallel by child orders.
forkList.childToId: List element for branch mapping: expects the name of an element within the selected list variable that holds a unique identifier for the branch that should be created dynamically.
forkList.joinIfFailed: A child order is terminated in case of failure. The parent order will be put to the FAILED state.
forkList.agentAssignment:
The ForkList Instruction is assigned a Subagent Cluster that specifies a number of Subagents on which jobs are executed in parallel. Two options for assignment are offered: 
 * selection of a Subagent Cluster that allows to select from a list. 
 * input of an expression that specifies the Subagent Cluster ID. This includes to specify a workflow variable, optionally carried by an order that specifies the Subagent Cluster.
forkList.subagent: Allows to select the Subagent Cluster from which all available Agents are used to execute in parallel jobs within the ForkList Instruction.
forkList.agentCluster: The Agent Cluster is selected from which the Subagent Cluster ID is specified by an expression in a separate input field.
forkList.subagentClusterIdExpr: The Expression specifies the Subagent Cluster ID from a variable. If no expression is specified then the js7ForkListSubagentClusterId variable will be used. If a variable is specified then it should hold the Subagent Cluster ID.
forkList.infoOfListVariable: For use of the ForkList Instruction with a list variable see the documentation at %https://kb.sos-berlin.com/x/ZLrAAw%
forkList.infoOfSubagentCluster: For use of the ForkList Instruction with a Subagent Cluster visit the documentation at %https://kb.sos-berlin.com/x/KQiwBQ%

stickySubagent.agentAssignment:
The StickySubagent Instruction is assigned a Subagent Cluster that specifies a number of Subagents from which one Subagent will be selected. Two options for assignment are offered: 
 * selection of a Subagent Cluster that allows to select from a list. 
 * input of an expression that specifies the Subagent Cluster ID. This includes to specify a workflow variable, optionally carried by an order that specifies the Subagent Cluster.
stickySubagent.subagent: Allows to select the Subagent Cluster from which one Subgent will be used to execute jobs within the StickySubagent Instruction.
stickySubagent.agentCluster: The Agent Cluster is selected from which the Subagent Cluster is specified by an expression in a separate input field.
stickySubagent.subagentClusterIdExpr: The Expression specifies the Subagent Cluster ID from a variable. If no expression is specified then an arbitrary Subagent of the given Agent Cluster will be used. If a variable is specified then it should hold the Subagent Cluster ID.

if.predicate: A Predicate in an If Instruction is an expression or comparison that evaluates to 'true' or 'false'

job.name: A job name is unique in a workflow. A job with the same name can occur with a number of Job Instructions in the same workflow if individual job labels are used. For a job name most unicode characters can be used, dots and hyphens, however, no spaces, no leading or trailing dots or hyphens.
job.label: A job Label is used to distinguish multiple occurrences of a job with the same name in a workflow.
job.title: The Title of a job can be specified as desired. The Title becomes visible with the WORKFLOWS view.
job.compatibleMode: Compatibility with previous JobScheduler versions includes e.g. for shell jobs to automatically create environment variables prefixed with 'SCHEDULER_PARAM_' for any order variables as in JS1.
job.credentialKey: A Credential Key can be added to the Windows Credential Manager holding the credentials that are used to switch to a target user account for this job. Optionally a user profile can be loaded.
job.loadUserProfile: Load Windows User Profile. A profile includes e.g. environment variables and Windows registry settings. This setting can be used only if a Credential Key is specified.
job.returnCode: By default Return Code 0 signals successful execution, a non-zero return code signals failed execution. Any number of return codes signaling success or signaling failure can be specified by a comma separated list.
job.checkSteadyState: When a file arrives in a directory that is watched for incoming files then the file size and file timestamp are checked for changes. Between each check the specified delay is applied until no further changes can be observed.
job.jobClass: The Job Class determines if a job is executed with the OS Shell (Windows, Unix, MacOS) etc.) or is executed as a JVM JITL Java job or is executed as a JVM Script job for one of the scripting languages supported by the JVM.
job.timeout: When exceeding the Timeout then with Windows a job is aborted. With Unix the job is sent a SIGTERM signal and after the Grace Timeout a SIGKILL signal will abort the job.
job.graceTimeout: A Grace Timeout is applied to jobs with Unix that receive a SIGTERM signal when exceeding their Timeout. If the job does not terminate then after the Grace Timeout a SIGKILL signal will abort the job.
job.warnIfShorter: If the execution period of a job is shorter than specified then a notification, e.g. by e-mail, is sent. The number of seconds can be specified as in 1s. Alternatively the hh:mm:ss format can be used, for example 01:30:00 for one and a half hours. A percentage can be specified that is calculated from the average of successful past job executions, for example 30%.
job.warnIfLonger: If the execution period of a job is longer than specified then a notification, e.g. by e-mail, is sent. The number of seconds can be specified as in 1s. Alternatively the hh:mm:ss format can be used, for example 01:30:00 for one and a half hours. A percentage can be specified that is calculated from the average of successful past job executions, for example 30%.
job.fileWatcher: File Order Sources are used to watch a Directory for incoming files and to create an order with the respective workflow for each file.
job.className: The name of a Java class implementing a job. JS7 ships with a number of predefined JITL Java classes, e.g. for database access, to send e-mail etc.
job.parallelism: The max. Parallelism specifies the number of orders in a workflow that can execute the job in parallel. If the max. Parallelism is exceeded then orders have to wait until the value has fallen below the job's max. Parallelism.
job.criticality: The Criticality of jobs can be used in notifications to better distinguish the urgency of an incident.
job.failOnOutputErr: If a job writes output to the stderr channel then this is considered an error and the order is put in the FAILED state.
job.warnOnOutputErr: If a job writes output to the stderr channel then this is considered a warning. Job execution is considered successful and the order continues. A notification is created for the warning.
job.admissionTime: Admission Times rule access to jobs based on weekdays and hours. An order waits in front of a job node until the admission time is reached or can be configured to skip the job if admission times do not meet the order date.
job.skipIfNoAdmissionForOrderDay: The job is skipped if admission periods have been configured that do not match the order's date. For example, if admission periods are configured for Monday and Tuesday, but the order is scheduled for Wednesday then the job will be skipped. On Monday and Tuesday the order will wait with the job instruction until the admission time is reached.
job.mailTo: Send e-mail to the indicated recipient. A number of e-mail addresses can be specified separated by a comma.
job.mailCC: Send e-mail copy to the indicated recipient. A number of e-mail addresses can be specified separated by a comma.
job.mailBcc: Send e-mail blind copy to the indicated recipient. A number of e-mail addresses can be specified separated by a comma.
job.mailOn: Send e-mail in case of the indicated events of errors, warnings or success.
job.description: The Description is displayed when this job is selected from the list of Job Templates.
job.onWarning: A number of Return Codes can be specified that signal successful execution with warnings. A notification is created in case of such return codes. A number of return codes can be specified by a comma separated list.
job.agentAssignment: The Job is assigned an Autonomous Agent or Subagent Cluster for execution. Within a block of ForkList or StickySubagent Instructions an Agent Cluster is assigned. As an alternative an Expression can be specified that provides the unique Subagent Cluster ID from a variable.
job.agent: The job is assigned an Agent that will execute the job script/class. Select from the list of available Agents.
job.agentCluster: Selects the Agent Cluster for which a Subagent Cluster ID is specified from an expression in a later input field.
job.subagentClusterIdExpr: The Expression specifies the Subagent Cluster ID from a variable. If no variable is specified then a built-in default becomes active if the job is included with a ForkList or StickySubagent Instruction. Users can specify an individual variable for example if predecessor jobs are used to determine the Subagent Cluster on which to execute a successor job.

admissionTime.admissionType: The type of admission times includes to specify Weekdays, Specific Weekdays and Month Days.
admissionTime.weekDays: Weekdays specify days of week that can be individually selected.
admissionTime.monthDays: Month days are counted from the first to the last day of month or vice versa.
admissionTime.dayNumber: Specific weekdays allow to determine the recurrence of the weekday in a month, for example the first, second, last etc. occurrence.
admissionTime.startTime: The period begin specifies when a cycle will initially become active. Values are specified from the hh:mm:ss format, for example 00:00:00 indicates midnight.
admissionTime.duration: Specifies the duration for which the cycle is active. Values are specified in hours, minutes or seconds, for example 1h, 3600s, 60m, or from the hh:mm:ss format, for example 01:00:00.
admissionTime.cycleType: The type of cycle is one of periodical (individual start times per period), continuous (fixed pause between start times) or ticking (fixed start time interval).
admissionTime.periodical: The periodical cycle type allows to specify individual start times per period in seconds or minutes, for example: 0, 15m, 25m, 47m. In this example the cycle will start at the begin of each hour and at the 15th, 25th and 47th minute provided that an hourly period is specified.
admissionTime.continuous: The continuous cycle type specifies a fixed interval, i.e. a pause, between the last cycle run and the next cycle start indepndently from the execution time that might be different per cycle run.
admissionTime.ticking: The ticking cycle type specifies a fixed interval between cycle starts, for example every 5 minutes, independently of the time used to execute the cycle. If a cycle runs longer than its start time interval then it will be restarted immediately after its last run.
admissionTime.interval: The interval for the ticking cycle type specifies the frequency of cycle runs, for example every 5 minutes. Values can be specified in hours, minutes, seconds, for example 1h, 60m, 3600s. In addition the hh:mm:ss format can be used as in 01:00:00 for an hourly cycle run.
admissionTime.pause: The pause for the continous cycle type specifies the interval between completion of the last cycle and start of the next cycle. Values can be specified in hours, minutes, seconds, for example 1h, 60m, 3600s. In addition the hh:mm:ss format can be used as in 01:00:00 for a one hour's pause between cycle runs.
admissionTime.limit: For the continuous cycle type a limit for the max. number of cycle runs can be specified.
admissionTime.offsets: The offsets for a periodical cycle type specify the points in time within the given period when the cycle starts. Values can be specified in seconds or minutes, for example: 0, 15m, 25m, 47m. In this example the cycle will start at the begin of each hour and at the 15th, 25th and 47th minute provided that an hourly period is specified.
admissionTime.period: The period specifies the duration for which a cycle is active. The cycle will start from the period begin and will be repeated according to its cycle type for the specified duration.
admissionTime.periodBeginOfAdmissionTime: Specifies the begin of the job's admission times. Values are specified from the hh:mm:ss format, for example 00:00:00 indicates midnight.
admissionTime.durationOfAdmissionTime: Specifies the duration of the job's admission times. Values are specified in hours, minutes or seconds, for example 1h, 3600s, 60m, or from the hh:mm:ss format, for example 01:00:00.

addOrder.workflowName: The AddOrder Instruction allows to add an independent order to the specified workflow.
addOrder.arguments: Arguments have to be added to the Order if required by the target workflow. Optional arguments can be omitted.
addOrder.remainWhenTerminated: After termination the Order remains with the workflow. This requires to manually perform the operation 'Leave Workflow' that is available from the WORKFLOWS view.
addOrder.startPosition: Allows to select the start position of the order in the workflow. Without a start position, the orders starts from the beginning of the workflow.
addOrder.endPositions: Allows the selection of one or more end positions of the order in the workflow. Without an end position, the order ends with the end of the workflow.
addOrder.ignoreAdmissionTimes: The execution of jobs can be restricted by Admission Times of the jobs. This option ignores Admission Times and forces the start of jobs.
addOrder.blockPosition: An order can be added to the position of a specific block instruction, for example to a branch in a Fork Instruction, to a Lock Instruction etc. at any nesting level of workflow instructions. The order will leave the workflow when reaching the end of the block instruction. When selecting a block instruction then start position and end positions are specified within the scope of the block instruction.

lock.name: Names of Resource Locks are unique in the inventory. Sections in workflows can be limited in parallelism by using Resource Locks.
lock.count: The Weight for use of a Resource Lock is calculated towards its capacity. If the capacity is exceeded then the order has to wait until a capacity is available that matches or exceeds the current weight.

prompt.question: A Prompt Instruction includes that workflow execution will be temporarily stopped. The order is put in the PROMPTING state. User can check the Message that is associated with the Prompt Instruction and can confirm execution of the workflow. The order will then be put in the RUNNING state.

retry.maxTries: When reaching the max. number of Retries then the Try Instruction ends and the order is put in the FAILED state.
retry.delay: The Delay specifies the time in seconds before the next retry is performed. If a number of values are specified - separated by a comma - then each value from left to right applies to the period that the next retry is waited for.

cycle.onlyOnePeriod: A cycle can specify more than one period, for example for 1pm, 2pm, 3pm with each cycle lasting for 30 minutes. By default an order arriving at 1.45pm will run both cycles for 2pm and 3pm. When using the setting 'One period only' then an order will run the first matching period only and will not consider later periods.

export.useRelativePathOnly: When exporting scheduling objects then by default an absolute path is used. Users can specify a relative path to be used starting from the selected folder. If no folder is selected but scheduling objects only then using a relative path maps to exporting as top-level objects to the export archive file.

placeholder.search: Search in Name or Title using for example '%search%'

tooltips.search: Search is performed for the name or title of objects. If further search criteria are specified from next lines in this form, then they are combined by 'and'. If search criteria are specified from the same line, for example if alternative checkboxes are offered then they are combined by 'or'.
tooltips.folders: Select one or more Folders to filter results.
tooltips.currentController: Limit results to objects available with the Current Controller.
tooltips.deployedOrReleased: Limit results to objects that are Deployed/Released.
tooltips.return: Specify the object types to Return

message.selectWorkflowToOpenJobEditor: Select workflow to open job in Job Editor

license.firstWarning: The JS7 license expires on {{date}}. Get in contact with %Sales Team% for license renewal.
license.secondWarning: The JS7 license expired on {{date}}. Cluster instances of JOC Cockpit, Controller and Agents are out of service.

login.message.operationTimeoutOrCancelled: The operation timed out or was cancelled
login.message.notSecureConnection: Your connection to JOC Cockpit is not secure. Use of the Identity Service requires a secure HTTPS connection.

register.message.registrationSuccessful: Your registration request is accepted and will be verified.
register.message.verifyEmailAddress: To complete your registration, please check your inbox for a message asking to verify your e-mail address.
register.message.updateToModernBrowser: We recommend updating to a modern browser that supports WebAuthn for the best user experience and increased security.
register.message.tokenExpired: The token is expired or broken.
register.message.mailVerifiedMessage: Your e-mail address has been verified successfully.
register.message.newFIDOAccountRegistration: Please start over with a new security key registration.

order.placeholder.enterCycleEndTime: Enter value as hh:mm:ss or seconds
order.message.orderModificationNotAllowed: The order state {{state}} does not allow modification
order.message.noLogHistoryFound: No log found for this order
order.tooltip.cycleEndTime: Optionally specifies the cycle end time. Users can specify a shorter period than predefined for the cycle to terminate. The order will be resumed from the position choosen by the user and the specified end time will be checked when the order returns to the begin of the cycle. Cycle end times exceeding the predefined cycle period will be ignored.

profile.label.maxEntryPerPage: Max. number of entries per page
profile.label.maxNumberOfAuditLogEntries: Max. number of Audit Log entries
profile.label.maxNumberOfAuditLogPerObject: Max. number of Audit Log entries per object
profile.label.maxNumberOfOverviewEntries: Max. number of Order Overview entries
profile.label.maxNumberOfDailyPlanEntries: Max. number of Daily Plan entries
profile.label.maxNumberOfWorkflowEntries: Max. number of orders per Workflow
profile.label.maxNumberOfFileTransferEntries: Max. number of File Transfer entries
profile.label.maxNumberOfResourceLockEntries: Max. number of orders per Resource Lock
profile.label.maxNumberOfNoticeBoardEntries: Max. number of orders per Notice Board
profile.label.maxNumberOfHistoryEntriesPerOrder: Max. number of Order History entries per Workflow
profile.label.maxNumberOfHistoryEntriesPerTask: Max. number of Job History entries per Workflow
profile.label.showFilesImmediately: Show Files immediately in File Transfer view
profile.label.entryPerPage: Default number of entries per page
profile.label.useTimezoneForLog: Use time zone for log timestamps
profile.message.passwordNotMatch: New password and confirmed password have to match
profile.message.passwordShouldNotSame: Old password and new password cannot be the same

keyManagement.tooltip.import: Import public/private key from external CA

gitManagement.message.deleteGitCredentials: Deleting Git credentials will permanently remove them from the credentials list.

agentJobExecution.placeholder.enterAgentUrls: Enter Agent URLs separated by comma

calendar.message.calendarNotUsed: This Calendar is not yet used

documentation.message.documentNotUsed: This Documentation is not yet used

cleanup.time_zone: Specifies the time zone that is applied to the start time and period of the Cleanup Service.
cleanup.period: Specifies weekdays on which the Cleanup Service is performed. The first day of week is considered being Monday. When initially installing JS7 then the distribution specifies the full week. Without this setting the Cleanup Service will not start.
cleanup.period_begin: Specifies the start time of the Cleanup Service for the given period, e.g. on a daily basis.
cleanup.period_end: Specifies the end of the period for which the Cleanup Service is allowed to run. If the Cleanup Service is earlier to complete its task then it will stop before the indicated time. However, it will not continue to run beyond the indicated time.
cleanup.batch_size: Specifies the number of records that are purged within a single transaction. Increasing this value can improve performance, at the same time it will increase the risk of conflicts with concurrent transactions should parallel Services operate on the database.
cleanup.order_history_age: Specifies the retention period for the execution history of orders and tasks. Any history entries older than the value specified will be purged.
cleanup.order_history_logs_age: Specifies the retention period for order logs and task logs. Any logs older than the value specified will be purged. Consider that this value should not exceed the value of the cleanup_order_history_age setting as otherwise no navigation to logs can be offered by the JOC Cockpit GUI.
cleanup.daily_plan_history_age: Specifies the retention period for the history of the Daily Plan. Any history entries older than the value specified will be purged.
cleanup.deployment_history_versions: Specifies the number of versions per deployed object that should be retained. Such versions can be used to re-deploy an object from an older state. Any earlier deployed versions of deployed objects are removed.
cleanup.audit_log_age: Specifies the retention period for the Audit Log. Any audit log entries older than the value specified will be purged.
cleanup.file_transfer_history_age: Specifies the retention period of the File Transfer History. Any history entries older than the value specified will be purged.
cleanup.monitoring_history_age: Specifies the retention period of the Monitoring History. Any history entries older than the value specified will be purged.
cleanup.notification_history_age: Specifies the retention period of the Notification History. Any history entries older than the value specified will be purged.
cleanup.max_pool_size: The max. connection pool size specifies the number of database connection used. For environmentns with larger numbers of daily task history entries to purge it can be benefitial to increase this value for example to 10. Users have to check that their DBMS allows an increased number of connections to be used.
cleanup.profile_age: Specifies the max. number of days that a Profile has not been used from login by a user account before it is purged.
cleanup.failed_login_history_age: Specifies the max. number of days for which entries in the history of failed logins are retained before they are purged.

dailyplan.time_zone: Specifies the time zone that is applied to the start time of the Daily Plan Service and period of the Daily Plan.
dailyplan.start_time: Specifies the start time to run the Daily Plan on a daily basis with the indicated time zone. Without this setting the Daily Plan will run 30 minutes before the point in time specified by the period_begin setting. This setting accepts a time value, e.g. 23:00:00.
dailyplan.period_begin: Specifies the begin of the 24 hours Daily Plan period with the indicated time zone.
dailyplan.days_ahead_plan: Specifies the number of days ahead for which orders are generated and are made available with the PLANNED state.
dailyplan.days_ahead_submit: Specifies the number of days ahead for which PLANNED orders are submitted to Controllers and are made available with the SUBMITTED state.

joc.force_comments_for_audit_log: Specifies that for any changes applied to an object such as to add an order, to cancel an order etc. a reason has to be added for the Audit Log.
joc.comments_for_audit_log: Specifies a list of predefined reasons that is made available when adding reasons to the Audit Log is enforced.
joc.default_profile_account: Specifies the account that is used to populate profiles for any new accounts.
joc.enable_remember_me: Specifies that the login window offers the 'remember me' checkbox to store credentials with the browser.
joc.copy_paste_suffix: Specifies the suffix to be used for object names when performing copy & paste operations.
joc.copy_paste_prefix: Specifies the prefix to be used for object names when performing copy & paste operations.
joc.restore_suffix: Specifies the suffix to be used for object names when performing restore operations.
joc.restore_prefix: Specifies the prefix to be used for object names when performing restore operations.
joc.import_suffix: Specifies the suffix to be used for object names when importing objects from an archive file.
joc.import_prefix: Specifies the prefix to be used for object names when importing objects from an archive file.
joc.show_view_filetransfer: Specifies that independently from user permissions the FILE TRANSFERS view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_dashboard: Specifies that independently from user permissions the DASHBOARD view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_dailyplan: Specifies that independently from user permissions the DAILY PLAN view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_workflows: Specifies that independently from user permissions the WORKFLOWS view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_resources: Specifies that independently from user permissions the RESOURCES view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_history: Specifies that independently from user permissions the HISTORY view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_auditlog: Specifies that independently from user permissions the AUDIT LOG view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_configuration: Specifies that independently from user permissions the CONFIGURATION view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.show_view_monitor: Specifies that independently from user permissions the MONITOR view is available (=true) or is hidden (=false). An empty value for this setting specifies that user permissions determine if the view is displayed.
joc.controller_connection_joc_password: The password is used for authentication of the JOC service account (running in JOC Cockpit) with the Controller. If HTTP connections are used then the password is the only means for authentication. If HTTPS connections with mutual authentication are used then the password is not relevant as certificate based authentication is in place. An empty password can be specified with the corresponding password in the Controller's private.conf file being "plain:". If the password is modified in the JOC Cockpit Settings page then it has to be modified in the Controller's private.conf file too to make the passwords match. It is recommended to first modify the password in the active Controller instance's private.conf file and then in the Settings page. Then restart the Controller instance from the Dashboard view. JOC Cockpit will reconnect to the active Controller instance. If a Controller Cluster is used, then apply the same change to the passive Controller instance's private.conf file.
joc.controller_connection_history_password: The password is used for authentication of the History service account (running in JOC Cockpit) with the Controller. If HTTP connections are used then the password is the only means for authentication. If HTTPS connections with mutual authentication are used then the password is not relevant as certificate based authentication is in place. An empty password can be specified with the corresponding password in the Controller's private.conf file being "plain:". If the password is modified in the JOC Cockpit Settings page then it has to be modified in the Controller's private.conf file too to make the passwords match. It is recommended to first modify the password in the active Controller instance's private.conf file and then in the Settings page. Then restart the Controller instance from the Dashboard view. JOC Cockpit will reconnect to the active Controller instance. If a Controller Cluster is used, then apply the same change to the passive Controller instance's private.conf file.
joc.encoding: The Encoding is applied if JOC Cockpit is operated for Windows environments. Windows does not support Unicode but makes use of code pages. In case that the Windows code page cannot be detected automatically users can specify the code page, for details see https://kb.sos-berlin.com/x/h7J2B
joc.log_ext_directory: Specifies a directory that is accessible for JOC Cockpit and to which copies of order log files and task log files will be written.
joc.log_ext_order_history: Specifies that a JSON file holding information about the order history is created in case of successful orders, failed orders or both.
joc.log_ext_order: Specifies that an order log file is created in case of successful orders, failed orders or both.
joc.log_ext_task: Specifies that a task log file is created in case of successful task, failed tasks or both
joc.log_maximum_display_size: JOC Cockpit offers log output for display with the Log View window if the size of uncompressed log output does not exceed this value. Otherwise the log is offered for download only. The size is assumed in MB.
joc.log_applicable_size: If the value for the size of a job's log output is exceeded then the History Service will truncate the log output and will use the first and last 100 KB for the task log. The original log file will be removed. The size is assumed in MB.
joc.log_maximum_size: If the value for the size of a job's log output is exceeded then the History Service will truncate the log output and will use the first 100 KB for the task log. The original log file will be removed. The size is assumed in MB.
joc.joc_reverse_proxy_url: If JOC Cockpit is not accessible from its original URL but from a reverse proxy service only then this value specifies the URL to be used, for example with e-mail notifications.
joc.allow_empty_arguments: By default empty arguments are not allowed from Jobs and Job Templates as this forces jobs to distinguish between empty and unset variables. Users can enable the behavior to allow empty arguments.
joc.allow_undeclared_variables: Allow undeclared variables from orders. This includes that an order can carry variables that are not checked for their data type or mandatory use. Jobs will fail when referencing undeclared variables that are not available with an order.

user.welcome_got_it: Specifies that the welcome window that offers defaults and examples for download should no longer be displayed.
user.welcome_do_not_remind_me: Specifies that for the welcome window that offers defaults and examples for download no reminders should be active.

git.git_hold_workflows: Specifies if Workflows should be considered local to an environment or are intended for rollout with Git.
git.git_hold_calendars: Specifies if Calendars should be considered local to an environment or are intended for rollout with Git.
git.git_hold_schedules: Specifies if Schedules should be considered local to an environment or are intended for rollout with Git.
git.git_hold_notice_boards: Specifies if Notice Boards should be considered local to an environment or are intended for rollout with Git.
git.git_hold_resource_locks: Specifies if Resource Locks should be considered local to an environment or are intended for rollout with Git.
git.git_hold_script_includes: Specifies if Script Includes should be considered local to an environment or are intended for rollout with Git.
git.git_hold_file_order_sources: Specifies if File Order Sources should be considered local to an environment or are intended for rollout with Git.
