ldap.iamLdapHost: Expects the hostname or IP address of the LDAP Server Host. If TLS/SSL protocols are used then the Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) of the host has to be used for which the LDAP Server SSL certificate is issued.
ldap.iamLdapProtocol: The LDAP Protocol can be Plain Text, TLS or SSL. Plain Text is not recommended as the user account and password will be sent through the network without encryption. TLS and SSL protocols are considered being secure as they encrypt the connection to the LDAP Server.
ldap.iamLdapPort: The port that the LDAP Server is listening to. For Plain Text and TLS connections frequently port 389 is used, for SSL connections port 636 is a frequent option.
ldap.iamLdapAD: This checkbox simplifies the configuration if the LDAP Server is implemented by Active Directory. A number of attributes for user search and group search are automatically assumed if Active Directory is used.
ldap.iamLdapADWithSamAccount: The sAMAccountName attribute is the unique identifier of a user account. This attribute frequently is available with LDAP Servers of type Active Directory.
ldap.iamLdapWithMemberOf: The memberOf attribute simplifies the search for Security Groups for which the user account has membership. This attribute frequently is available with LDAP Servers of type Active Directory, however, other LDAP products similarly can implement this attribute.
ldap.iamLdapSearchBase: The Search Base for looking up user accounts in the hierarchy of LDAP Server entries, for example OU=Operations,O=IT,O=Users,DC=example,DC=com.
ldap.iamLdapGroupSearchBase: Similarly to the LDAP Search Base the Group Search Base is used to find Security Groups that a user account has membership for.
ldap.iamLdapUserDnTemplate: The Distinguished Name (DN) identifies a user account. In case of Active Directory LDAP Servers the value {0} can be used that is replaced by the user account specified during login. Alternatively an LDAP query can be specified, for example uid={0},OU=Operations,O=IT,O=Users,DC=example,DC=com
ldap.iamLdapServerUrl: The LDAP Server URL specifies the protocol, e.g. ldap:// for Plain Text and TLS connections, ldaps:// for SSL connections. The protocol is added the hostname (FQDN) and port of the LDAP Server.
ldap.iamLdapGroupNameAttribute: The LDAP Group Name attribute provides the name of the Security Group that a user account is a member of, for example the CN (Common Name) attribute.
ldap.iamLdapUserNameAttribute: The LDAP User Name attribute provides the name of the user account, frequently the CN (Common Name) attribute is used.
ldap.iamLdapGroupSearchFilter: The LDAP Group Search Filter specifies an LDAP query that is used to identify Security Groups the user account is a member of.
ldap.iamLdapUserSearchFilter: The LDAP User Search Filter specifies an LDAP query that is used to identify the user account in the hierarchy of LDAP entries.
ldap.iamLdapUseStartTls: The LDAP Start TLS switch makes TLS the protocol for the connection to the LDAP Server
ldap.iamLdapHostNameVerification: The LDAP Host Name Verification switch has to be active to check if hostnames in the LDAP Server URL and in the LDAP Server certificate match.
ldap.iamLdapGroupRolesMap: The LDAP Group/Roles Mapping is in fact a mapping of Security Groups that the user account is a member of and JS7 roles. Security Groups have to be specified depending on the LDAP Group Search Attribute as Distinguished Names, e.g. CN=js7_admins,OU=Operations,O=IT,O=Groups,DC=example,DC=com, or as Common Names, e.g. js7_admins.
ldap.iamLdapTrustStorePath: The path to a Truststore that holds the LDAP Server certificate or Root CA certificate used to sign the LDAP Server certificate.
ldap.iamLdapTrustStorePassword: If the LDAP Truststore is protected by a password, then the password has to be specified.
ldap.iamLdapTrustStoreType: The LDAP Truststore Type can be PKCS12 or JKS (deprecated).
ldap.iamLdapSystemUser: If an LDAP System User Account is specified, the 'bind' operation is performed with this account. If the setting remains empty, then the 'bind' operation is performed with the user account of the login.
ldap.iamLdapSystemPassword: An LDAP System User Password is usually required when an LDAP System User Account is specified.

vault.iamVaultUrl: The URL by which the Vault Server REST API is accessible.
vault.iamVaultTrustStorePath: The path to a Truststore that holds the Vault Server certificate or Root CA certificate used to sign the Vault Server certificate.
vault.iamVaultTrustStorePassword: If the Vault Truststore is protected by a password, then the password has to be specified.
vault.iamVaultTrustStoreType: The Vault Truststore Type can be PKCS12 or JKS (deprecated).
vault.iamVaultApplicationToken: The Vault Application Token is an Application Role token created for JOC Cockpit that allows to store user accounts and password to Vault.
vault.iamVaultAuthenticationMethodPath: The Vault Authentication Method Path specifies the path for which the Vault authentication method has been created, e.g. userpass, userpass_js7, ldap etc.

keycloak.iamKeycloakTrustStorePath: The path to a Truststore that holds the Keycloak Server certificate or Root CA certificate used to sign the Keycloak Server certificate.
keycloak.iamKeycloakClientId: The Keycloak Client ID is registered with Keycloak and has to match the value specified with the Identity Service settings.
keycloak.iamKeycloakTrustStorePassword: If the Keycloak Truststore is protected by a password, then the password has to be specified.
keycloak.iamKeycloakTrustStoreType: The Keycloak Truststore Type can be PKCS12 or JKS (deprecated).
keycloak.iamKeycloakClientSecret: The Keycloak Client Secret is registered with Keycloak and has to match the value specified with the Identity Service settings.
keycloak.iamKeycloakRealm: The Keycloak Realm is registered with Keycloak and has to match the value specified with the Identity Service settings.

oidc.iamOidcName: The name of the Identity Service using OIDC.
oidc.iamOidcAuthenticationUrl: The OIDC Authentication URL is the endpoint to which the JOC Cockpit GUI (Client) performs authentication.
oidc.iamOidcClientId: The OIDC Client ID is registered with the OIDC Identity Provider and has to match the value specified with the Identiy Service settings.
oidc.iamOidcClientSecret: The OIDC Client Secret is registered with the OIDC Identity Provider and has to match the value specified with the Identiy Service settings.
oidc.iamOidcTruststorePath: The path to a Truststore that holds the OIDC Identity Provider certificate or Root CA certificate used to sign the OIDC Identity Provider certificate. In case of known Certificate Authorities the path to the 'cacerts' truststore of the JDK/JRE in use can be specified.
oidc.iamOidcTruststoreType: The OIDC Truststore Type can be PKCS12 or JKS (deprecated).
oidc.iamOidcTruststorePassword: If the OIDC Truststore is protected by a password, then the password has to be specified.
oidc.iamOidcUserAttribute: The OIDC User Attribute is specific for an Identity Provider and indicates the name of the attribute that holds the unique identifier of a user that is used for login, for example the attribute 'email' specifies the user's e-mail address to be used for login.
oidc.iamOidcImage: If an OIDC Image is specified then it is displayed with the login screen. Image files of type .png are allowed with a maximum size of 1 MB. Images are best displayed using a width and height of 96 pixels.
oidc.iamOidcGroupClaims: OIDC Group Claims specify the groups for which the user account in question has membership. Each group can be mapped to one or more roles in JS7.
oidc.iamOidcGroupRolesMap: OIDC group memberships are each mapped to one or more JS7 roles.

webauthn.iamTimeout: The Timeout applied for User Verification. If the timeout is exceeded then the registration/authentication flow will be cancelled.
webauthn.iamTransports: Transports limit the type of connection that is accepted between the Client (JOC Cockpit GUI in the browser) and the Authenticator. Connections can for example include USB for connected USB Sticks and NFC to connect to smartphones.
webauthn.iamUserVerification: User Verification is the process of challenging the user to perform a gesture that proves the user's presence and consent. This can include to touch a USB stick, to use a fingerprint sensor, to perform face recognition etc.
webauthn.iamResidentKey: The Resident Key ('discoverable credentials') requirement specifies that the user's private key is stored in the security key. For FIDO2 and Passkey protocols a Resident Key is required.
webauthn.iamAuthenticatorType: The Authenticator Type can be 'roaming' or 'platform'. Roaming Authenticators ship on a security key such as a USB Stick or smartphone and limit availability of the user's private key to the respective device. Platform Authenticators store the user's private key on the platform, for example on a computer or phone and allow the private key to be replicated to other user devices such as tablets. Platform authenticators frequently store security keys in the cloud to allow synchronization with user devices.
webauthn.iamRequireAccount: The requirement to specify the user's Account during authentication can be considered an additional authentication factor. During registration users have to specify an account, when it comes to authentication then JS7 administrators can force the account to be specified.
webauthn.emailSettings: E-Mail Settings include to specify the mail server connection and the events on which e-mail will be sent for confirmation or notifiation purposes.
webauthn.jobResource: The E-mail Job Resource specifies a reference that holds variables required for the connection to the mail server. This includes the mail server's SMTP hostname, port, protocol and authentication used when sending mail.
webauthn.contentType: The E-mail Content Type frequently specifies 'text/html' or 'text/plain' for the format of the mail body.
webauthn.charset: The E-mail Charset specifies the character set used for the mail body which frequently is 'ISO-8859-1' or 'UTF-8'.
webauthn.encoding: The Encoding should be '7-bit' unless there is good reason to assume that higher encodings will be supported by mail clients.
webauthn.priority: The Priority specifies the respective flag that will become visible with the recipient's mail inbox.
webauthn.subject: The Subject of the related mail.
webauthn.body: The Body of the related mail can be specified as HTML or as plain text depending on the Content-Type setting in use.
webauthn.cc: CC means that carbon copies are sent to the indicated mail addresses of recipients. If more than one recipient is specified then they have to be separated by comma.
webauthn.bcc: Bcc means that blind carbon copies are sent to the indicated mail addresses of recipients. If more than one recipient is specified then they have to be separated by comma.
webauthn.recipient: The Recipient is specified by its mail address.
webauthn.sendMailToConfirmEmail: Send mail to user to confirm e-mail address
webauthn.sendMailToNotifyConfirmationReceived: Send mail to administrator to notify about successful confirmation
webauthn.sendMailToNotifyRegistrationEmail: Send mail to user to notify about successful registration

general.sessionTimeout: A user session will be terminated by JOC Cockpit and the user has to login after the given number of seconds if no action is performed in JOC Cockpit.
general.initialPassword: When user accounts are added then they are assigned an initial password that has to be changed with the next login.
general.minPasswordLength: Password strength preferably depends on length. A password that is shorter than the specified Minimum Password Length will be denied.
